HABITATSPEC_RELIAB: Expert opinion
HABITATSPEC_NOTES: Swan workshop. RP: Nests in the hollows of mature Marri Corymbia calophylla, Jarrah Eucalyptus marginata and Karri E. diversicolour in south-west forests and may only breed in years when Marri is fruiting in abundance. Feeds on Marri and Jarrah in south-west forests and Blackbutt E. patens, Albany Blackbutt E. staeri, Sheoak Allocasuarina fraseriana, Snottygobble Persoonia longifolia. Also feeds on the non-indigenous native Spotted Gum E. maculata and Cape Lilac Melia azedarach on the Swan Coastal Plain.
NOTES1: Swan workshop: past pressures & future threats

RP: Nests in the hollows of mature Marri Corymbia calophylla, Jarrah Eucalyptus marginata and Karri E. diversicolour in south-west forests and may only breed in years when Marri is fruiting in abundance. Also feeds on the non-indigenous native Spotted Gum E. maculata and Cape Lilac Melia azedarach on the Swan Coastal Plain.
NOTES1: Wheatbelt workshop: sometimes seen in subregion but not thought to be breeding in subregion.

HABITATSPEC_RELIAB: Expert opinion
HABITATSPEC_NOTES: RP: Nesting habitat - Nests in the hollows of mature Marri Corymbia calophylla, Karri Eucalyptus diversicolour and Jarrah Eucalyptus marginata in the lower south-west. Feeding habitat: Mainly feeds on the seeds and flowers of Marri in the forested regions of the south-west, the seeds of the Proteaceous Banksia grandis, B. littoralis, B. ilicifolia, Hakea undulata, H. prostrata, H. trifurcata, and Dryandra spp., as well as Erodium botrys, Jarrah and insect larvae. Also feeds on apple and pear seeds in orchards.
NOTES1:
WAM: Occurs in south-western humid and subhumid zones, north to Gidgegannup, east to Clackline, Wandering, Quindanning, the Perup River, Lake Muir and King River, and west to eastern strip of Swan Coastal Plain including West Midland, Gosnells, Byford, North Dandalup, Yarloop, Wokalup and Bunbury also the Stirling and Porongurup Ranges and along the south coast to Waychinicup
National Park. It is endemic to Western Australia.

AOOAREA_NOTES: Garnett et al 2011: 2500000ha at State level or 1,000,000ha based on area most birds occupy during winter; area of habitat declining especially due to loss of nest trees.
HABITATSPEC_RELIAB: Expert opinion
HABITATSPEC_NOTES: RP: Nesting habitat - Nests in the hollows of mature Marri Corymbia calophylla, Karri Eucalyptus diversicolour and Jarrah Eucalyptus marginata in the lower south-west. Feeding habitat: Mainly feeds on the seeds and flowers of Marri in the forested regions of the south-west, the seeds of the Proteaceous Banksia grandis, B. littoralis, B. ilicifolia, Hakea undulata, H. prostrata, H. trifurcata, and Dryandra spp., as well as Erodium botrys, Jarrah and insect larvae. Also feeds on apple and pear seeds in orchards.

KNOWNPOPS_NOTES: South West & Warren workshop: number of pops & trend, 1 failed translocation; 1 additional translocation too early to determin success. RP: 102 subpops in 2007, none new and loss of 26 subpops between 2007 and 2012, overall trend towards smaller populations and increased extinctions. JM: subpops in RP are delineated within a population by a distance of 50m along the same creek line but not separated by a physical barrier, change of land use or lack of survey (ie. not necessarily biological populations), workshop info used.

KNOWNPOPS_NOTES: MAP: Dampier peninsula, central deserts (Gibson, Little Sandy and Great Sandy Deserts), Pilbara, Francois Peron NP (reintroduced 1997), Lorna Glen (reintroduced), currently 2 reintrductions? JM: MAP advises translocation to Lorna Glen but not date, likely within last 10 years but workshop advised loss of Dryandra population was thought to occur in 2012, overall Static? MAP is not obvious if these are thought to be poppulations. Mammal workshop: unknown number of populations and trend, 4 reintroductions.
MATIND_NOTES: MAP:  WA 5000-10000 non-reintroduced (mean 7500), thought to be declining Australia-wide but not noted for WA. Translocated pops are small numbers. Mammals workshop & Keith Morris: no population estimates or trends available for WA, bilbies are hard to detect for presence absence and range over a wide area.
EOOAREA_METHOD: Alpha hull (alpha = 5) using point occurrence records in DPaW corporate database
EOOAREA_NOTES: S&C figure, trend from mammal workshop, loss of Dryandra population approx 2012, certainty of expert opinion = probable. Mammal workshop advised to recalc using additional data. MAP advises no change in extent in eastern WA over past decade (Ngaanyatjarra Lands), however no trends stated for other areas of the State. Notes from workshop: recalc with additional data

AOOAREA_NOTES: MAP. S&C: 39600ha. Mammal workshop advised to recalc using additional data.

KNOWNPOPS_NOTES: EPBC lisiting advice:  Pops listed are Margaret, Scott, Donnelly, Gardner, Shannon, Deep, Kent and Denmark Rivers, and Lake Quitjup, Lake Muir, Doggerup Creek, Broke Inlet and Two People’s Bay Watersheds; however, distribution is severely fragmented, with populations restricted to only a few streams within these river systems; Blackwood River catchment not counted as population but listed as found in 1 freshwater location; trend Static last 10 years, historic loss of northern distribution (Moore River to Capel River).

DPAWREGION: Wheatbelt, Swan, Southwest, Warren, South Coast
KNOWNESU_RELIAB: Expert opinion
KNOWNESU_TRENDRELIAB: Expert opinion
KNOWNESU_NOTES: Woinarski et al 2014: taxonomic dispute, not formally described. Thought to be Phascogale tapoatafa (south-western Australia) across SW of WA. Kimberley subspecies is thought to be a separate taxon but unable to obtain genetic samples from Kimberley animals.
KNOWNPOPS_CAT: Less than or equal to 10 (potentially meets location/subpopulation criteria VU)
KNOWNPOPS_RELIAB: Expert opinion
KNOWNPOPS_NOTES: Mammal workshop: taxonomy is very unclear, very cryptic species, hard to sample and estimate population numbers and AOO
MATIND_NOTES: Mammal workshop: taxonomy is very unclear, very cryptic species, hard to sample and estimate population numbers and AOO. Woinarski et al 2014: >10000 and decreasing but based on interstate data.
EOOAREA_NOTES: S&C: 6892434 or 5355823. However rejected by the mammal workshop on the basis of taxonomic and identification uncertainty. Woinarski et al 2014: 665720000ha for whole of taxon and decreasing but based on interstate data.
AOOAREA_NOTES: S&C: 173600. Woinarski et al 2014: taxon has disappeared from semi arid SW of WA and may have declined in the last 10 years  - fewer records despite increased survey effort. Fluctuations in response to climatic conditions. Status in the Kimberley is unclear as there are few recent records. Woinarski et al 2014: 270000ha and decreasing but based on interstate data.

NOTES1: S&C: not though to be extant in WA, last records 1969 from Nullarbor. Nullarbor is part of former distribution in the Mammals of Australia. The species was listed in WA in 1990 due to the clarification of taxonomy. WA assessments include National distribution the species was listed as threatened (not presumed extinct) and the Nullarbor is a poorly surveyed area of the State.

NOTES1: S&C: This taxon has never recorded alive in WA but sub-fossil records suggest widespread WA distribution, eg Cape Range, where the species has been recorded from 12 caves. These deposits are consistent with accumulations deposited by owls and are considered to be of recent origin. The species is considered part of the modern Western Australian mammal fauna and when rediscovered near Alice Springs in 1996, it was listed WA (assessments for listing include National distribution the species).

KNOWNESU_NOTES: Larson et al 2013: Milyeringa veritas redescribed to include Cape Range distribution only, M brooksi was previously described but this paper sinks that taxon back into M veritas, some genetic structuring within M veritas

KNOWNPOPS_NOTES: Page et al 2008: known from 5 wells or caves on Cape Range.

KNOWNPOPS_TRENDRELIAB: Quantitative analysis of data published or publically available following peer review
KNOWNPOPS_NOTES: Garnett et al 2011: loss of Ord pop 2003; Skroblin & Legge 2013 advise that it was surveyed and found to be absent in King George catchment. Garnett et al 2011: extant in Fitzroy, Isdell, Drysdale, Durack & Pentecost.
MATIND_RELIAB: Quantitative analysis of data published or publically available following peer review
MATIND_TRENDRELIAB: Quantitative analysis of data published or publically available following peer review
MATIND_NOTES: Skroblin & Legge 2013: Fitzroy (1434 to 2467; mean 1950) + Isdell (85 to 147; mean 116) + Drysdale (393 to 677; mean 535) + Durack (905 to 1557; mean 1231) + Pentecost North (17 to 30; mean 23) = 2834 to 4878; total mean 3855; declining trend; Garnett et al 2011: upper Fitztroy <1000, Drysdale approx 1500, King George <500 unknown for Isdell and Pentecost (total 7300 includes NT pops). All refs note declining trend. JM: pops counted as number of catchments intersected by subregional boundaries so I have used the same approach for number of individuals, however there is a significant over estimate at subregional level due to double counting.  JM: Garnett et al 2011: King George catchment <500 but Skroblin & Legge 2013 advise that it was surveyed and found to be absent from this catchment, loss of population.
EOOAREA_CAT: < 10,000,000ha (does not meet IUCN extent of occurrence criteria)
EOOAREA_METHOD: Alpha hull (alpha = 5) using point occurrence records in DPaW corporate database
EOOAREA_NOTES: Kimberley workshop: S&C polygon ok 1536489. JM: loss of Ord pop but I am unsure of which datapoint to exclude from calc therefore polygon area kept; loss of King Goerge pop but this was not included in S&C polygon anyway; loss of part pop Pentecost South but this is within polygon. Garnett et al 2011: 16900000ha but includes NT.
AOOAREA_CAT: < 1,000ha (potentially meets area of occupancy criteria for CR)
AOOAREA_NOTES: Skroblin & Legge 2013: 305km riparian vegetation (suitable habitat).

KNOWNPOPS_RELIAB: Quantitative analysis of data published or publically available following peer review
KNOWNPOPS_TRENDRELIAB: Quantitative analysis of data published or publically available following peer review
KNOWNPOPS_NOTES: NMc: 3 Pilbara - eastern Pilbara, Hamersley Range and northern Gascoyne; needs old caves/mines refuge. Disjunct distribution from Kim/NT form and Pilbara form is at physiological limits. Significant survey effort in last 10 years has increased number of known roost sites but no change to number of populations. Significant threat but no loss of whole pops yet, future loss predicted. Loss of roost site at Bamboo Creek within last 10 years.   JM: Not sure how many pops for Kimberley/NT but at least 1.

MATIND_NOTES: Woinarski et al 2014 & Cramer et al 2014: no current estimates of abundance, decreasing.
EOOAREA_CAT: > 10,000,000ha (does not meet IUCN extent of occurrence criteria)
EOOAREA_NOTES: Woinarski et al 2014: 11,030,000ha & Static. Woinarski et al 2014: increase from 11 known roost sites in 2010 to over 20 in 2014 due to survey effort. JM: increase due to survey effort.
AOOAREA_CAT: < 1,000ha (potentially meets area of occupancy criteria for CR)
AOOAREA_NOTES: NMc: advised use of <1000ha to count roost sites only, caves & old mine works only. Woinarski et al 2014 includes two figures for AOO (578300ha or 659400ha according to different methodolgies).
HABITATSPEC_RELIAB: Quantitative analysis of data published or publically available following peer review
HABITATSPEC_NOTES: NMc: use of mine adits is new habitat type but this occurred before last 10 years. Cramer et al 2014: Stable microclimate with constant high temp and humidity is required. Structural properties of roof, entrance and proximity to foraging areas are unknown.
NOTES1: NMc: Montypic genus, unique foraging strategy. Threatened status from Pil, not threatened in Kim. JM: surveys from threatened fauna database. NMc & Woinarski et al 2014: past pressures & future threats.
PASTPRESSURES_SPECIFY: habitat loss of roost sites in caves due to mining of orebodies; collapse of old mine diggings; sensitivity to disturbance of roost sites (abandonment of roosts)
FUTURETHREATS_SPECIFY: habitat loss of roost sites in caves due to mining of orebodies; collapse of old mine diggings; sensitivity to disturbance of roost sites (abandonment of roosts)
MANREQ_RESEARCH_CAT: Au iii) Ecological niche and life history (forecasting changes in populations)
MANREQ_RESEARCH_SPECIFY: identify and confirm diurnal roost sites as distinguished from caves with nocturnal visitation, particularly in areas where mining is planned.
MANREQ_EVALUATION_CAT: EV v) Compile and synthesis existing data on occurrences and state (specify source of data)
MANREQ_CONSPLAN_CAT: CP ix) Other management plan (specify)
MANREQ_CONSPLAN_SPECIFY: management & protection guidelines required for roost sites
MANREQ_DIRECT_CAT: MD ix) Translocation
MANREQ_DIRECT_SPECIFY: assess adoption by bats of artificial roosts excavated into non-prospective hard rock strata near existing natural roosts in iron-rich strata
MANREQ_INDIRECT_CAT: MI ii) Habitat protection through other statutory mechanisms (specify)
MANREQ_INDIRECT_SPECIFY: conservation covenants for roost sites  (particularly maternity roost sites) where appropriate
NOTES2: JM: NMc advised to use management actions in Woinarski et al 2014 so I have added these.

MANREQ_RESEARCH_SPECIFY: determine current population size

MANREQ_RESEARCH_CAT: MA iv) Mitigating threatening processes – species
MANREQ_RESEARCH_SPECIFY: define appropriate buffers so mining activities do not lead to abandoment of roosts, assess effectiveness
MANREQ_INDIRECT_CAT: MI x) Regulation - Native vegetation clearing/pollution

MANREQ_RESEARCH_CAT: IN viii) Quantification of detectability of threatened & priority taxa
MANREQ_RESEARCH_SPECIFY: develop non-invasive cost effective monitoring protocols with defined trigger points and contingency actions; develop a set of standard guidelines for mining proponents to follow in order to resolve the presence of this species in project area
MANREQ_INDIRECT_CAT: MI xi) Regulation - environmental impact assessment

MANREQ_RESEARCH_CAT: SC ii) Phylogeography & genetic variation/structuring
MANREQ_RESEARCH_SPECIFY: resolve taxonomy of Pilbara and Northern Australia populations
MANREQ_INDIRECT_CAT: MI xii) Assessment of compliance to approval/conditions/land use under legislation and/or enforcement of legislation

MANREQ_RESEARCH_CAT: Au iv) Autecological information (to improve management effectiveness)
MANREQ_RESEARCH_SPECIFY: identify seasonal access to foraging areas remote from major roosts; assess proximity to roosts of foraging habitats used by lactating females compared to other adults
MANREQ_INDIRECT_CAT: MI xii) Planning processes

KNOWNPOPS_NOTES: NMc: East Pilbara main distribution shared with PIL04 & GSD01. MATIND_RELIAB: Quantitative analysis of data published or publically available following peer review
MATIND_TRENDRELIAB: Quantitative unpublished data and expert opinion
MATIND_NOTES: MC: this taxon is hard to find in the wild, and not seen as frequently as in previous decades but this could be because of decline in knowlede of where/how to find them or actual decline in numbers of individuals. Vulnerable to predation & changed fire regimes and these threats have been ongoing. Pop size for Rudall River is unknown

KNOWNESU_NOTES: RP: five distinct geographical groupings (mangagement units/populations) - Shark Bay area, the wheatbelt, the Abrolhos and granite outcrops in the Murchison River catchment near Cue (black form), considerable phenotypic plasticity with the species. JM: Baudin Island was also idendified in the RP but this is listed as a separate taxon Egernia stokesii aethiops.
KNOWNPOPS_CAT: Less than or equal to 5 (potentially meets location/subpopulation criteria EN)

KNOWNPOPS_NOTES: RP: uses geographical groupings and populations interchangably so ESU info and pops are the same for this taxon. Historic decline in distribution/populations but before last 10 years.
MATIND_NOTES: Midwest workshop: number of individuals unknown, trends as per AOO. RP: no info on numbers of individuals.

NOTES1: EPBC listing advice 2010: Marine species, although it has been found on inshore reefs. Previously found at Ashmore and Hibernia Reefs, but thought to have disappeared from these reefs by 2000 and no other known populations. Some records from NT but likely to be vagrant. JM: Ashmore and Hibernia Reefs are not in WA State waters so not included in Audit II.

EPBC listing advice 2010: Marine species, although it has been found on inshore reefs and on Pilbara coast. Previously found at Ashmore and Hibernia Reefs, but thought to have disappeared from these reefs by 2000 and no other known populations. Some records from Pilbara coast but origin of these specimens has not been determined (they
may have been vagrants or they may represent a population which has not yet been identified). JM: Ashmore and Hibernia Reefs are not in WA State waters so not included in Audit II.

MATIND_NOTES: Garnett et al 2011: Charadrius mongolus mongolus 12,000 + Charadrius mongolus stegmanni 12,000 = 24,000 Australia-wide; both subspecies decreasing in number of mature individuals 84% across 49 Australian sites between 1983 and 2007.
EOOAREA_NOTES: Garnett et al 2011: 3,530,000ha for whole of Aust, trend. JM: EOO N/A for this taxon at State or subregion scale, calculated polygon is incorrect. S&C: 19,796,890ha
AOOAREA_NOTES: Garnett et al 2011: 260,000ha for both subspecies; not available at State or subregional scale.

Habitat is coastal wetlands.

MATIND_TRENDRELIAB: Quantitative unpublished data and expert opinion
MATIND_NOTES: Moir and Chen Lang 2013 & TSSC nomination form:  Unknown number of individuals but host plant, Banksia montana has almost been extinguished at Bluff Knoll due to severe fires and  Dieback. The mealybug is only found on the oldest plant at this site, suggesting that it hasn’t had time to colonize younger plants and has been extinguished on other plants during fires.
